text:
I’ve always wanted to buy an interail ticket for a month and fully travel Italy ! However work annual leave probably wouldn’t allow that. So thinking of splitting it in half, same thing but 2 weeks in either the north or the south, summer 2024 for my 30th birthday. Then the other half another year.

Struggling to decide which to pick north or southआणखी 🤦🏼‍♀️

I want to see tourist hot spots but also get to see the inbetween bits by train travel and hopefully get some off the beaten track experiences to treasure.

Currently learning Italian and my Nonna was Italian and can’t help feel a connection to the country I want to know and see the ins and outs of.

Recommendations welcome ☺️

comments.comment_text: Since you splitting it, doing one 1st and then the other, then it really doesn't matter if you start north or south unless it's winter vs summer.
Depending on season, south is very hot in the summer, north is hot but milder so if traveling different seasons over the two years then consider that

South definitely
I’ve done both
South more hospitable 😀

Phoe i wuold say 2 weeks is to short anyway:) and north or south are both good as long as you do'nt go north of lake garda. Not that its not beautifull over there but the food gets a little less. Lake como is more quiet and beautifull than garda but the food is less. In the north as you want to vist citys i would chose florance,venice
of verona little more south i would do rome afcourse and sicly is realy nice as well it all depends on what you want beach,city or nice litle towns on the coast ofr in the mountains its all possible in italy
Where is your nonna from? Maybe use that to make your decision unless of course she is from the middle lol

Rent a car. Land in Milan, leave from Rome. Drive up to Como, to Venice, across Tuscany to Pisz, Florence, Rome, Naples, Almafi, to Alberobello, back to Rome and Arrivaderci.
Plenty of time to get a great taste of all. Maybe even time for Rimini. Perhaps save Alberobello for next trip with Puglia and Calabria
Google Maps dnd Booking .com are great help. Don't pre book.

Depends on your budget and what kind of things you like. South is a bit easier on your budget. It has plenty of Roman and medieval stuff. North is pricier, but it has the iconic cities like Venice and Florence.
Food is amazing everywhere, but if you are vegetarian, some places are easier.
In my opinion, it’s harder to do the south (including Sicily) without a car.
Should have mentioned, I have already been to Treviso, Venice & Rome, so wouldn’t need to go to those
I recommend not going in the summer if you can avoid it!!

If I were you, I would stay north for the first trip. Why? Because you have written "summer 2024". The second trip go to the south, but think Spring or Fall. I do not travel to Italy during the summer - too busy with tourists and can be very hot.
Sounds outstanding, I would say based on the time of the year you plan your trip if it’s summer head north.

We spent a month this April and May only using trains. The Italian train system is a dream! Download the Trenitalia app.

3 hour from Naples to Florence! 180 MPH! Turin to Milan. 1 hour almost 200 MPH. Connections a breeze.

We are so jealous
F
Sicily.

Go to eurail.com and check the cost of the Italian passes. Going for two weeks is cheaper than two one-week trips.if you just do the north, you can finish your trip by zipping down to Rome and flying out of Rome and whetting your appetite for a southern trip at the same time.(It’s a 4hour trip from Verona to Rome by train)
Where is your family from? I would start there. We just took the train from Rome to Sicily and it was neat because you take a ferry across on the train.
Start in the south and work your way up. Those that started up north and then went south were a little disappointed.
If you do the northern part, you must visit the Dolomites; they are absolutely gorgeous and not over crowded with tourists!
You are young. Get a job there and experience Italian life.

Definitely agree with several others about the summer being hot and crowded. If you can even move your trip to September it makes a huge difference in temp, fewer peeps, and accommodation prices go down a little.

If you want to move by train, it can makes sense “divide” Italy in “Adriatic side” and “Tirrenian side” more then north and south.
The connection through Appennini are difficult by train, except for the leg Bologna-Florenc
e (and viceversa of course).
About what area is better… Italy is all beautiful! 💚🤍❤️

I am doing this, this year! I just spent 2 and half weeks on holiday from work, then returned to Uk for a week. In that time I travelled to some of Eastern Europe. Then next week I am flying to Germany, coming through the alps by train and reaching Bergamo, where I will fly to Palermo and spent 10 days working my way back up. My work situation is different as I have a child so I am allowed 2 weeks a year unpaid to spend some time with her. So I took that option. Interrailing is awesome
If you read the posts in this group everyone is going to the same places... I would avoid them. I went south and loved it, not crowded and georgous places to see.
South is the best..where was your Nonna from?
Go north, visit Verona and Vicenza

Depends on time of year. Hotter in south. Avoid the heat. Colder in the north. If you go to Alps or Dolomites, avoid heavy winter and reduced travel. I would start in north in April or May, September or October. Just my opinion.

I would start with a good travel book. Rick Steves or Foders. Well worth taking a few day to read up and plan.
Trains are best booking as you need them. Very reasonable and train passes rarely pay off.

I would factor in where you are coming from and how you're getting there and back. I would make it the easiest quickest way first as that will give you more time for the actual travel first time around. One of the things we found (on a 3 month trip) is we didn't realise how long it would actually take to go as far as we thought we wanted (keeping in mind we could afford to spend more time in some places).

It all depends on your interests....bo
th have tons to offer

Im going to be visiting south Italy end of September and was just wondering what is the best way to get from Naples airport to Sorrento and then from Sorrento to Positano and then from there up to Rome?
First time visting Italy so any helpful tips/must do things to see and visit is greatly appreciated.

Thanks
Emma

Depends on how much you want to spend! You can get a bus to the train station in Naples and then get a train to Sorrento.

There is no train between Sorrento and positano so you would get a local bus.

Heading to Rome you could probably get a transfer from positano to Naples train station and then get the fast train from Naples to Rome (it’s only an hour) or get a bus from positano to Sorrento. Train from Sorrento to Naples and then train from Naples to Rome!

More expensive options are car rental or transfers!

Best way Napels airport to Sorrento is Curreri bus for 10 euros.
Sorrento to positano by sita bus to go and by boat to come back.

Train direct from Naples to sorrento local line no need to book,
Sorrento to positano bus a couple of euros , train back to Rome

Campania express train Naples to sorrento (more expensive but more comfortable than circumvesuvia - 15 euros instead of 2.60 euros approx)
Sorrento ferry to Positano and back - buy ticket on the day.
Speed train from Naples to rome is just over an hour. Frecciarossa…

text:
Still in Rome
1. Taxi- need to go to an official taxi pick up location with a sign not just hail a cab
You can google taxi stand near me
If u so manage to get one outside a designated area they will gouge you on price
2. Get in shape
We have been walking 15-20k steps a day
I sure wish I had prepared and walked more in advance but thankfully their is motrin and wine

comments.comment_text: I just said to my husband that I needed to get my steps in!!! Wine doesn't sound bad for an excuse 😂
Motrin and wine lol I love that

So I was in Perugia for a week before Rome so that was where I prepared for Rome and trust me Perugia is much worse. Lol. Everything there is straight up or straight down walking. There's no even surfaces. Rome was a cakewalk in comparison. 🤣 For taxis you don't necessarily have to go to a taxi stand. You can use itaxi or Uber to get a taxi from anywhere to anywhere which I had to do several times because I was nowhere near a taxi stand. However when I left to go to the airport there were six taxis lined up at a taxi stand so I had absolutely no problem getting back to the airport on time.
I feel your pain, we were just in London. We walked about the same.

Also confirm your price before you get in the taxi. We went to the official stand between the Vatican and Castel Sant’Angelo a year ago and a cab driver tried quoting us a ridiculous price (like 50 euros) to go to over to Palazzo Navona. We refused to pay and approached another driver who yelled at the guy trying to rip us off. He was honest and wonderful and refused to take a tip from us. So yes, always get a quote before you jump in a cab even at an official taxi stand.
Uber black was very inexpensive (compared to taxis) and so easy to use. Download the App. 15 euro for 3 ppl, from pantheon to the Vatican.
Sightseeing is hard work! Training required for all those steps, and break in your shoes before you leave.
They do have Uber in Rome as an option, not very cheap but you know the cost when booking at least
You can use Freenow App. It’s cheaper than Uber. 🙂

Take the metro A line toward Battistini e get off at the Ottaviano stop and then walk to the Vatican. Or you can also take a taxi.

I was in Rome last week, and the metro is very easy to navigate. If you have an iPhone you can use the maps app and switch from drive to transit and it’ll tell you which metro line to take and which stop to get off of. We got a day pass for the metro for 7 euros a person and we found it very easy to navigate the city that way.

text: Do you need to get an international driving permit to drive a scooter?? Or does your local driver’s licence work for that?

comments.comment_text: International licence to drive in Italy is required.
What about hiring a car do we need international permit? We have full UK license
No you need to get an intrnational permit
You need the same driving license you need for a car although you should get an internatiinal one in your country of residence.
Can foreigners drive in Italy? Yes, if you're visiting, you'll need to have an International Driving Permit (IDP) along with your legal driving license.
Yes
Check your insurance policy too. They may not pay out if you don’t have one. They don’t cost much so best to be safe rather than sorry.
Just do it. It takes 10 minutes
Yes. They're simple, quick and inexpensive. You need it if you get in an accident or pulled over.

Whether a car, scooter or m/bike you will always need an International driving license to drive overseas, thems the rules.
Sometimes people only find the proper rules when their insurance gets cancelled after an incident or when stopped at a random police stop.
If you have a US drivers license and you’re going to drive an automobile in Europe, you need to get an international drivers permit. And usually get those at AAA.
I never actually thought about that. There were tons of people on scooters in Rome but I never thought to ask them if they had to have any kind of special license for them.

text: We will be staying at Airbnb in Venice and Milan, do they provide shampoos and conditioners? It indicates that it comes with a washer, do they provide laundry detergent? Do we have to bring our own? Your advice greatly appreciated! thanks in advance

comments.comment_text: You would want to send an email to the host
Can you ask the Airbnb? All are different, no way to no for sure unless you ask.
IF the Airbnb provides those items, I'm sure it will say in the description, I've usually found I need to provide my own.

All I have stayed at (which has been many) always provided them but the quality varied quite a bit. Some was pitiful and I went to a store the next more to get something different. Others have been so good (specifically soaps), that I found out where they bought it so I could get more...one even became my new daily soap. I do also travel with a small bar just in case.
You might want to check their Airbnb posting. Usually lists the amenities. If not, contact your host through the Airbnb site.
Contact your host
Why are you not asking the host?
We stayed in 3 Airbnbs recently. Some provided everything some did not. I would reach out and ask.
I’d contact the owner , we took our own wash pods , but most only had basic soap etc

I have found the detergent sheets very handy to have since many only provide a little detergent.
Most I’ve encountered in France and Italy only provide shampoo not conditioner. I brought my own.
Ask the owner , much more accurate answer that way
Communicate with your hosts directly. Each one is different.
Oh my gosh— these are questions for your Airbnb hosts!

I experienced a bit of both. Some had shampoo and no conditioner. Some had soap some didn’t. Some had dish soap some didn’t. I brought laundry pods with me. They don’t talk up much space. I bought shampoo there.
I travel with shampoo and conditioner bars. They work great and don’t take up room in your liquids bag. I also bring laundry detergent sheets.
It varies. Ask your host.
Detergent sheets and shampoo n conditioner bars
I am doing that and I brought shampoo, conditioner and laundry sheets.
Every Airbnb I used in Italy supplied all of that
It should be in the property info what is provided. It is for all ones I’ve looked at. And if you aren’t sure when read that contact host
There is no way for any of us to know what the Airbnb you booked will or won’t provide. Contact them directly.
Best to ask the owner.
Our place provided 2 washing machine packets but I bet you could get more if you asked. I have found in Europe shampoo is usually provided but conditioner was non existent in hotels and rentals

It varies, but I have noticed that not much is provided. I had one not even have toilet paper and another just have 1 roll of toilet paper. No shampoo or conditioner, not even hand soap. One place asked me to empty the garbage but did not provide any garbage bags for the kitchen or bathroom. Best to ask.
I take my own washing sheets that are like tissues, and most don’t have dryers only washing machines🌻

Just stayed in two and both provided bath items and detergent. I did bring detergent sheets (from Amazon and took no room) and a couple travel bottles. I would shoot them a note tho if you don’t want to bring anything.
Ask your host in advance! I did have those things provided at my air bnbs but best to check!
If they do they'll usually list it under the amenities. The places we stayed last year did not.
All the AirB&B’s we booked (11 of them) for next year all state if they supply it or not. Look at what this place offers list. It’ll be in bathroom list.
The ones we stayed in did. One had full size and one had travel size in a cute basket.
If not...then there are shops. .
Shampoo and conditions ussaly not there

I have just stayed at one and there was just enough laundry detergent to use the washing machine once (we stayed for 8 days, so we bought some). At the previous place there wasn't any. But at the previous one there was a full bottle. So it is a bit of a hit and miss.
I bring my own shampoo and conditioner. I would also recommend the detergent sheets because they take up literally no room and are as light as paper.
I'd say message the airbnb host as they differ in what's provided, ours has been great with answering our questions.

comments.comment_text: Italy is not a movie set. 99.9% of cities are normal cities where people live, not attractions

Local trains allow you to catch a different train but it does need to be planned, make sure there’s a later train available, we did this in Genoa, walked around the waterfront for a bit and had some lunch then went on to Nice, trains with reserved seats however require u to take that exact train that u booked

They do stop, but only for a few minutes. Before you know it the train is moving. Take something to keep you busy, the rides are not bad at all, especially riding in business or premium. We scheduled ours in the morning and used the time on them to get more rest and go over our itinerary for that day. Beautiful sceneries during the ride.
Naples is definitely a very different vibe compared to Rome or Florence, you’ll get a lot out of visiting different parts of the country!

We travelled from Florence to Lucca, which involved a change at Pisa. At Pisa we left the station, went to visit the tower, then walked back to get on a later train. All fine. No validation issues because we had validated our ticket in florence. All local trains so no assigned seating.
I'll say most stops don't look inviting.
If you buy a train pass for Italy you can have unlimited travel within the days you purchased so you could stow your luggage in a locker and visit a city before moving on

Have you considered using an interail pass for Italy ?
This enables you to travel and use extra train journeys within your travel pass days . Just a thought x

I purchased a eurail pass and it allows for unlimited travel on a given day. We travelled long distances but stopped at certain places to explore for a few hours. It made the journey so interesting. We were not in a hurry and I did not want to plan too much so this was a great solution as I could book the tickets a few minutes before boarding. One stop we got off and visited Monaco, they do not allow you to store luggage anywhere in that country so we had to carry it but we just got on the Hop on Hop Off bus and enjoyed the sights, then went back to the train and continued on to Italy. I wish i booked for more days than I did as it was very handy to have the ability to jump on and off at will. (With the exception of some trains that require reservations). You can get a pass just for only Italy but we got the global one and travelled from Amsterdam to Italy through Belgium, France, Monaco. Now planning our trip from Italy to Belgium to return home. It’s a great idea to do it! Sorry I can’t answer about normal train tickets. Good luck!

It's more work than you think to get on and off, deal with luggage, perhaps a different platform. We did an extra train (three instead of two) going from Brugge to Amsterdam so that we could see the Antwerp station. It was beautiful, but made for a long and exhausting day.

text:
I saw someone arguing over which side of the road we drive in italy so just if you are interested on renting a car, we drive on the right side of the road, and the cars have the pilot on the left side of the car. Tips for driving around big cities, always respect priority sign and red lights, don’t drive like you own the road (even if lots ofआणखी italians do that), and dont park outside of parking spots if you don’t want to take a salty fine. (N.B.: even if not common, THEY DO FINE IN BIG CITIES, better not risk it at all! )
Also be careful about parking stripes. White stripes, all good. Blue stripes, you have to pay €/hour parking. Yellow stripes are just for loading and unloading, but i see lot of people in Milan parking on yellow stripes and end up getting fined.
Hope you have a great stay in italy 🏎️

text: Train question: it was suggested to buy train tickets n advance and on longer trips, upgrade to business class. We are going to several cities. If we miss a train, can we get on the next one if there are seats? Do the tickets have to be validated at the station? I read to validate bus tickets at a yellow kiosk before boarding or be subjected to getting kicked off wherever you might be.

comments.comment_text: Read the conditions of each ticket purchase option before buying. Some are no change/no refundable at very attractive price

There is typically a bus validation machine-type thingy on each bus, one by the back door and one by the front. I suppose that one could use the train validation machine at the train station to validate your ticket, but I've only used the ones on the buses. Paper tickets for the train definitely need to be validated before you get on the train though, and it looks as though pretty soon we are going to need to validate our electronic train tickets online as well.

I notice that many are confused about ticket validation .
As a general rule, only tickets in which the seat is not reserved should be stamped. A ticket for a train with a seat already assigned, so typically Frecciarossa frecciargento Italo or IC, is already yours and can only be used on that specific train so validation is not needed. A ticket for a regional train is generally without a timetable or assigned seat, you could use it on any train even multiple times, so it obviously needs to be stamped to be in order. When you buy it online, usually in combination with other trains to switch with, it already has an assigned schedule for the regional train as well, so you don't need to stamp it.
That's why online tickets should not be validated, it has nothing to do with the way of purchase, but with the exact time and the ticket not usable multiple times.
For the same reason, these tickets not to be validated do not allow you to take other trains on the same route at other times. However, in some cases you can exchange them.

If you book ahead of time on an app then you don't need to validate.
When you book you'll be given options. Read carefully as to whether it's flexible.
I booked 13 trips on Trainline. None of mine could be used at different times.

text:
I’m seeing a lot of posts about pickpocketing. I’m planning on carry my valuables in a little bag with me at all times but I don’t want to be carrying my passport everywhere. Is it safe to leave it in my hotel? Also what about leaving things unattended when going for a swim in the ocean?

I appreciate all the posts from everyone in this group. It is helping me prepare for my trip coming up in 2 weeks.

comments.comment_text: Rome Venice and Milan are full of pickpockets, mainly at the big attractions and the metro they are literally all over the metro in Rome we saw many

Anything you leave unattended might not be there when you return.
Leave nothing of value.

I bought a waterproof phone carrier that I can stick my phone and valuables in to swim.

And a security sling bag that’s impossible to pickpocket.
If I put my bag down in a crowded area, I clip it to my belt.

Any other valuables will be in the safe at the hotel.

You want to take photos of your passports and credit cards Just in case.

If you have a photo of your passport, it’s easier at the Embassy if you do have to get an emergency passport.

I always keep an emergency credit card somewhere other than on my person.

You will not enjoy being stuck in Europe with no money.

If you don't look like an acceptable shade of color, you'll be stopped for random checks everywhere.
By law you need to carry original documents with you, it's also the same law for anyone legally residing in Italy.

If you're not the right color, you'll also be stopped to check your bags at shopping markets.

Europe is just "inclusive" like that.
If you understand what I mean by acceptable shade of color and non-acceptable shade of color, then make arrangements accordingly.

Good luck.

I left all valuables except for a small gold chain that could be worn at all times at home. Who needs these things and the added stress it brings while on a vacation? 🤷🏻‍♀️

We never noticed any pickpockets, we never once felt unsafe or threatened.

We also had other people take pictures of us (by lending our phone).

You can have an absolutely amazing, relaxing vacation by being smart and aware of your surroundings.

We didn’t leave our bags on the backs of chairs or under seats where they were out of sight or unattended. We kept our phones in zipped bags/purses on the front of our bodies. When we boarded public transit, or were in crowded places, we locked the zippers on our backpacks/
bags, but were still visibly vigilant too.

We did visit a hot spring and left our bags out of our reach — however, they were visible to us at all times and we locked the zippers, plus used a cable through the lock to attach to the tree.

Could someone still have stolen? Absolutely. But we were not easy targets.

We didn’t dress above the top, didn’t wear things to make us look like we had a tonne of money, and I personally carried my passport on me at all times, as I felt it was safer with me, then left at hotel/Airbnb etc.

All this being said: we didn’t visit Naples, which would come with its own set of rules for safety etc. 😊
It is safer with you than in the hotel. And if you put your things in your closed bag, nobody will steal it. Just do not carry things in your pocket or opened bag

No blanket answer for hotels anywhere in the world. You'll have to assess place by place. Personally I love going to a city where the worst thing I have to worry about is pickpocketing. Way better than worrying about being the victim of a violent crime in many US cities.

I take my passport everywhere. I have said it on other fb pages. You never know when you will be asked to present it AND you never know if there will be some kind of national disaster. Friends of mine were traveling in Norcia, Italy when the last earthquake hit. I would want my official ID with me at all times. Happy to wear it close to my body so as not to lose it.

We were just there last week and we were asked for passports at customs and checking into each hotel. We were not asked for passports at anything else. If you purchase something on the more expensive side you can be asked for it or a copy of it for the VAT tax. We weren’t buying anything like that so we never needed it.
We carried only what we needed for the day and left everything else locked in the room. We do hide our important things in the room.
Stop with the pickpocket stories and fears. You're safer in Italy than in many cities in the US.
There is no ocean in Italy. One can not go for a swim in the ocean while in Italy, no hard feelings, but one can not.
I ordered tickets for the Uffizi at a certain time and was told to bring ID

Take a copy of your passport when out and about and DO NOT carry your “valuables”in a small bag with you during the day walking around cities, they are much safer licked in hotel safe
Im presuming “valuables” might mean jewellery or credit cards
Money belt and bring your passport with you.
We never carry our passports. Take a pic to have on your phone and maybe a paper copy, too.

Random check by police on train Marsala-Trapani
.
Don't look like a tourist. Don't put all your eggs in one basket; therefore, wallet front pocket, documents front left.

I’ve always carried my passport wherever we go! I had a shoulder purse I keep in front close to me especially in a crowd. In the train it was so crowded someone tried to open my purse I pulled my purse even closer to me & looked at the woman in the eye she got off the train in a hurry… the other Italians saw it & told me “check your wallet “ in English “ they were very concerned. Hate to categorize but she looked like a Gypsy Roma… sometimes the pickpockets would wear a priest habit. So be very careful!
An over size wallet that is hard for you to get out of your pocket is impossible for a pick pocket to get. Never bring stuff to the beach and use the hotel room safe.
Lived there 6 years, never been pickedpocket not once, not even in other European countries.

Never, ever, no matter what country you're in leave valuables on the beach when you go for a swim. No one knows what hotel you're staying in, however, if it has a safe, use it, but don't forget your items. And yes, you are required to carry your passport.

Like a watch, diamond necklace???

Around the Colosseum we saw a group having to show their passports. A block away we saw another group of people being asked. Kind of sucks to have to be vigilant while also trying to relax and enjoy things…they’re literally opposites…my experience last month…zero incidents…nowhe
re felt unsafe…didn’t carry my passport everywhere…no one asked for it…you can ask 10 people they’ll say 10 different things but do whatever gives you peace of mind because it really comes down to your own personality

Ever. Does it happen? Yes just like it does in cities, towns and villages around the world. I wouldn't leave valuables on the beach unattended though. If you give someone an opportunity they will take it.
There are ways to get round it though.
Just be as safety conscious as you would in any city. There's plenty of anti theft backpacks/ bags you can get but even a normal handbag is fine.

safe- never a problem.

We have always safely left our passports in hotel safes. I generally would not leave things unattended on the beach but a workaround is to just bring towels and shoes and leave all the valuables in the room or safely in stored luggage.

Just got pack from Italy last week. We were asked for identity documents at almost every attraction which required timed entry tickets with named entrants (for example visiting The Last Supper in Milan). We were asked at every hotel check in and in some cases when purchasing train tickets (in Levanto when purchasing Cinque Terre regional day pass). We were travelling with a friend from the Philippines and he was asked to produce identity documents a couple of times. If you are a visible minority you will be asked. That said, l don’t know if a copy of passports would have sufficed. We carried our documents with us. Only one attempted pickpocketing on the Rome subway, otherwise we felt pretty safe.

Just to keep things in perspective, less than 1% of the more than 10 million tourists to Italy are victims of pickpockets. This group has been helpful in other ways but seems to generate a lot of paranoia around crime.
Lots of good answers. My opinion actually what I believe. Always take it with you. I trust myself before any safe or Hotel Manager. in the EU or US or any other country.

text:
🏛️Here is my “ self made “ itinerary for October 5th through the 17th for my husband, my 14-year-old son and myself.
Fly out on Thursday October 5th, land in Rome afternoon Friday the 6th and staying near, piazza Navona. will visit the Spanish steps, Trevi fountain, and the pantheon. Dinner and gelato
Saturday 7th = sistine chapel & Vatican museum and Evening night tour of Colosseum
Sunday 8th = mass at St. Peter’s and then get car to drive up to Tuscany area-
Spend Sunday the 8th night, 9th & 10th !?! montepulciano area …I need winery and hotel recommendations ….!! HELP needed here.
On 11th drive down to tour Pompeii - ( my son wants to see ) then stay in sorrento nights of 11th & 12th
On 13th drive to tropea spend the night there =dinner & walk around the town
14th drive to ferry to Sicily.
Stay in taoromina 14th and 15th.
15th drive to Cefalu spend night there.
16th drive to Palermo - spend one night- fly out 17th from there.
I have my airfare booked and most hotels - except Tuscany area, looking for advice - Should I spend one more day in Rome or should I keep the three days in Tuscany? Adding- We are pretty well traveled family so the schedule doesn’t really scare me. But advice and tips are welcome -
